State Key Joint Laboratory of Environment Simulation and Pollution Control School of Environment Tsinghua University Beijing 100084 PR China Graphical abstract Pt-Au/TiO2-CeO2 catalyst for the co-oxidation of HCHO, H2 and CO at 25 °C. The deactivation origins of the Pt-Au/TiO2-CeO2 catalyst for co-oxidation of formaldehyde (HCHO), hydrogen (H2) and carbon monoxide (CO) at room temperature were studied by means of XRD, BET, H2-TPR, O2-TPD, XPS and in-situ DRIFTS. The results suggested that the catalyst deactivation was mainly caused by the reduction of Au+ species, the decrease of Ce3+ species and interaction weakness between active components and support. Moreover, during the co-oxidation process, CO showed a negative influence on the oxidation of HCHO and H2 due to the CO self-poisoning effect, whereas H2 promoted the oxidation of HCHO and CO because of the generation of OOH and OH active intermediates from the H2 oxidation. Meanwhile, the accumulations of carbonate-like species as well as the production of H2O on the deactivated catalyst were also observed, accounting for the complete catalyst deactivation. Keywords Deactivation HCHO H2 CO Pt-Au/TiO2-CeO2 catalyst 1 Introduction Space capsule is important for the development of scientific research. In space capsule, formaldehyde (HCHO), hydrogen (H2) and carbon monoxide (CO) coexist, which originate respectively from the degradation process of macromolecular compounds, the charge-discharge procedure of battery, and human metabolism processes [1–3]. Long-time exposure to HCHO and CO would endanger human health [4], and H2 is inflammable and explosive. Therefore, it is necessary to develop new technologies to simultaneously remove HCHO, H2 and CO [5]. Supported noble metals catalysts always present completely different catalytic properties than noble metals and supports (metal oxides). This may be due to the strong interaction between the noble metal nanoparticle and the oxide support, which can significantly facilitate the catalytic activity [6,7]. Noble metal catalysts presented good catalytic activity on the removal of HCHO, H2 and CO. Pt catalysts showed high activity for the oxidation HCHO. It can be attributed to that formate species were easily decomposed to CO and then CO was oxidized to CO2 over these catalysts [6,7]. Meanwhile, H2 was facilely dissociated on these catalysts due to its low activation barrier of OH formation [8–11]. However, these catalysts were easily poisoned by CO attributed to the CO self-poisoning effect [12–14]. CO was more favorably adsorbed by Pt active species because of its higher sticking coefficient than that of O2 when CO could not be completely oxidized [12], which inhibited the effective O2 adsorption and resulted in the Pt catalyst deactivation. Au catalysts can weaken the CO self-poisoning effect and eliminate CO at low temperature (< 0 °C) [15,16], because activation energy barrier for CO oxidation on Au catalyst (0.18 eV) is lower than that those of Pt catalyst (0.96 eV) [11]. Due to the co-existence of HCHO, H2 and CO in space capsule [6], Pt-Au bimetallic catalyst was accordingly proposed for the co-oxidation of H2, CO and HCHO at room temperature. Previous studies [17,18] have suggested that bimetal catalyst showed high activity due to the synergetic effect between individual active site. Na et al. [17] have reported that Pt-Au bimetal catalyst presented higher catalytic activity than single Pt or Au catalysts for the simultaneous removal of CO and HCHO at 25 °C. While single Pd or Au catalysts can not co-oxide H2 and CO, supported Au-Pd/Fe(OH)x catalyst presents high activity for the simultaneous removal of CO and H2 [18]. Our previous reports showed that the catalytic activity of bimetallic Pt-Au/CeO2 catalyst was strongly influenced by preparation method [7] and doping TiO2 [19] into CeO2 support. The Pt-Au/TiO2-CeO2 catalyst with 5% (wt) TiO2 doped into CeO2 support showed the best activity for the simultaneous removal of CO, HCHO and H2 at 25 °C. Although massive studies reported deactivation mechanism of single noble metal catalyst [8,11,12,20], few works have been referred to the deactivation mechanism of the bimetal catalyst (Pt-Au) and mutual influence between reactants for the simultaneous removal of CO, HCHO and H2 at room temperature. Based on our previous studies [7,19], the bimetallic Pt-Au/TiO2-CeO2 catalyst was selected for the co-oxidation of CO, HCHO and H2 at room temperature. This work was focused on the deactivation mechanism and mutual influence between reactants on this catalyst. The deactivated catalyst was obtained after running for 75 h, then it was characterized using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), High Resolution Transimission Electron Microscop (HRTEM), and temperature programmed studies. The key intermediate species during reaction were identified with in-situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (In-situ DRIFTS) and the deactivation mechanisms were proposed. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalyst preparation CeO2 nanosphere was obtained through the hydrothermal method [18]. TiO2-CeO2 support (mTiO2/mCeO2 = 5%) was obtained by the direct precipitation method. CeO2 nanospheres were added into the tetra-n-butyl titanate ethanol solution, and the suspension was stirred for 2 h. Then pH value of the suspension was adjusted to 10 by ammonia solution. After that the suspension was filtered, solid sample was washed with ultra-pure water for three times. Solid sample was dried at 120 °C for 12 h. Then solid sample was calcined at 400 °C for 2 h under air. Pt-Au/TiO2-CeO2 catalyst was prepared by reduction and deposition precipitation method [21], and mole ratios of Ti/Ce and Au/Pt on the fresh sample were 5 % and 1 %, respectively. 4 g TiO2-CeO2 support was dispersed into the H2PtCl6 solution (0.04 g Pt) with being stirred for 2 h. Then NaOH solution was added into the suspension to adjust pH value (10). After that NaBH4 solution, with the molar ratio of NaBH4/Pt = 10, was fleetly dispersed into the suspension. The suspension was stirred for 2 h at 25 °C. Then suspension was filtered out, and solid was washed with ultra-pure water for three times. The solid sample was dried at 80 °C for 12 h under vacuum. 2 g Pt/TiO2-CeO2 and 0.8 g urea were added into the HAuCl4 solution (0.02 g Au). The suspension was keeped being stirred for 8 h at 80 °C, and then was aged at 25 °C for 12 h. The suspension was filtered out, and then was washed with ultra-pure water for three times. At last, solid sample was dried for 12 h under vacuum at 25 °C to get Pt-Au/TiO2-CeO2 catalyst. 2.2 Catalyst characterization XRD patterns were operated by a Shimadzu XRD-6000 diffractometer at 40 kV and 40 mA, with nickel-filtered Cu Kα (λ =0.1542 nm) radiation. Pt-Au/TiO2-CeO2 catalyst was added into ethanol under ultrasonic for 2 h to prepare HRTEM samples. HRTEM micrographs were obtained through a JEM-2100 F microscope. BET surface area of the catalyst was tested through N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms, on a Micromeritics ASAP 2000 instrument at low temperature. Before BET surface area test, catalyst sample was pretreated under vacuum at 300 °C for 6 h. Moreover, the pressure range (P/P0) of points was selected at 0.05-0.3 for BET surface area calculation. The surface chemical state of catalyst was investigated through XPS, PHI Quantro SXM ULVAC-PHI, Japan. The test was operated at 15 kV and 25 W using an Al Kα X-ray source (1486.7 eV). The binding energy calibrated by C 1s was at 284.8 eV. H2-TPR measurements were tested in a fixed bed microreactor, equipped with a mass spectrometer (Omnistar, GSD-301-O2). Before test, 0.2 g sample was pretreated for 1 h at 120 °C under Ar. Cooling to 25 °C, the catalyst was pretreated by 5% H2/N2 at 50 mL min−1. At the same time, the system temperature increased from 30 to 680 °C at the rate of 10 °C min−1. O2-TPO analysis was tested on a mass spectrometer OmniStar. 40 mg sample in a quartz reactor was pretreated with a He flow at 120 °C for 1 h. When the system temperature increased to 500 °C at a rate of 10 °C min−1 with the a 4% O2/He gas flow, the signals of O2, CO2 and H2O were collected. In-situ DRIFTS spectra were obtained through a Nicolet 6700 FTIR spectrometer. Before the experiments, catalyst sample was pretreated for 30 min at 120 °C under Ar. After the system was cooled to 25 °C, the reactant gas mixture (at 100 mL min−1) was led into the DRIFT cell. All spectra were collected with 4 cm-1 resolution through 32 scans accumulation. 2.3 Measurement of the catalytic activity Activity test for the simultaneous removal of HCHO, H2 and CO was investigated with 0.36 g catalyst sample at 25 °C. Before activity test, catalyst sample was pretreated for 1 h at 120 °C under Ar. After the system was cooled to 25 °C, the reaction gas contained 100 ppm HCHO, 100 ppm H2, 4000 ppm CO, and air with 50% RH (relative humidity), was led into the reactor at 2100 mL min−1, corresponding to 300,000 h-1 (GHSV). Gaseous HCHO was generated by flowing nitrogen through the paraformaldehyde container in a water bath kept at 35 °C. HCHO was tested through an acetylacetone-based spectrophotometric method. H2 was tested through a gas chromatograph (GC), CO and CO2 were tested by another gas chromatograph (GC) with a CH4 converter. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic performance The catalytic performance of Pt-Au/TiO2-CeO2 catalyst for the co-oxidation of HCHO, H2 and CO was investigated at 25 °C. As shown in Fig. 1 , the catalytic process can be divided into two stages. The 1st stage sustained around 20 h, during which the conversions of HCHO, H2 and CO are comparatively stable, maintaining at 80%, 77% and 85%, respectively. The 2nd stage, starting from 20 h, was characterized by the quick decrease of catalytic activity until 0 with time on stream. However, the conversions of HCHO, H2 and CO did not decrease synchronously. The catalytic oxidation activity of HCHO and H2 are very low after 60 h while the conversion of CO is still around 60%. This activity result indicates that the active sites for the oxidation of HCHO and H2 are different from that for the oxidation of CO. To elucidate the origins of the deactivation of Pt-Au/TiO2-CeO2 catalyst during the HCHO, H2 and CO co-oxidation process, physicochemical properties of the fresh and deactivated catalysts were further investigated. 3.2 Physicochemical properties of catalysts Firstly, the XRD patterns of the fresh and deactivated Pt-Au/TiO2-CeO2 catalysts were performed and shown in the Fig. 2 . It is obviously found that all diffraction peaks are attributed to cubic CeO2 (JCPDS 43-1002), and no diffraction peaks assigned to TiO2, Pt and Au species are detected in all catalyst samples. Furthermore, diffraction peak intensity of deactivated catalyst is a little bit lower than that of fresh catalyst, suggesting that physicochemical property of CeO2 has been modified [21]. The HRTEM images of the fresh and deactivated Pt-Au/TiO2-CeO2 catalysts as well as the CeO2 nanospheres are shown in Fig. 3 . The reflection through a d spacing value of 0.23 nm attributed to Pt (111) plane and the Au (200) reflection through a d spacing value of 0.20 nm present in both fresh and deactivated Pt-Au/TiO2-CeO2 samples [22]. No obvious aggregation of Pt and Au species can be observed in two samples, which is in accordance with the XRD results. Therefore, the particle growth of Pt and Au species probably is not the origin of catalyst deactivation. It is worth mentioning that BET surface areas of fresh and deactivated catalyst are 133.6 and 110.7 m2 g−1, respectively, which suggests that the decrease of BET surface area should not be the main origin of catalyst deactivation. Fig. 4 shows H2-TPR profiles of the fresh and deactivated catalysts. For the fresh catalyst, four reduction peaks are observed at 70, 144, 322, and 451 °C, respectively. The reduction temperature of cationic Pt species is in the range of 70–100 °C [23] and the peak at 70 °C is assigned to the reduction of cationic Pt species. The peak at 144 °C is assigned to the reduction of cationic Au species [24], and the peak at 322 °C is assinged to the reduction of surface oxygen species on CeO2 [25]. The peak at 451 °C can be attributed to the reduction of surface CeO2 (Ce4+ to Ce3+) [26]. However, there are only two reduction peaks at 144 and 469 °C were observed over the deactivated catalyst. The reduction peak at 70 °C disappears, which reveals the absence of cationic Pt species. The reduction peak intensity at 144 °C is lower than that on fresh catalyst, meaning that the loss of cationic Au species occurs during the reaction. The reduction peak at 322 °C disappears is due to the CeO2 surface oxygen was completely consumed on the deactivated catalyst. In addition, the reduction temperature of CeO2 shifts to higher temperature, suggesting that the reduction of CeO2 is more difficult on the deactivated catalyst. Reduction peak changes of CeO2 surface oxygen and surface CeO2 may be caused by the interaction change between CeO2 and TiO2 [21]. XPS measurement was performed to study the chemical states of active species on the fresh and deactivated Pt-Au/TiO2-CeO2 catalysts. Fig. 5 shows Au and Pt4f spectra of the fresh and deactivated catalysts. The peaks at 83.7 and 84.6 eV are assigned to Au0 and Au+ respectively [27]. Results of the Au4f spectra suggest that both Au0 and Au+ species exist in the fresh catalyst. However, only Au0 species can be observed in the deactivated catalyst. Previously studies showed that cationic Au species present higher activity than metallic Au species for the CO oxidation [28,29]. Consequently, the decrease of cationic Au species is one of the reasons for the catalyst deactivation. Moreover, the binding energy (BE) of Au4f in deactivated catalyst presents a negative shift of 0.4 ev compared to that of fresh catalyst (84.3 eV). It indicates the reduction of Au speices, which may be cuased by the electron transfer from CeO2 and TiO2 supports to Au+ species, thus increasing the Au species electron density during the co-oxidation process [30,31]. The electron transfer results in the reduction of Au+ species and enhances the interaction between the Au species and support oxides. Therefore, an in-depth understanding and optimization of the strong metal-support interaction (SMSI) occurring at the metal/oxide interface is significantly for the design of high-performance catalysts [15,17–19]. For Pt4f spectra, peaks at 70.7 and 71.6 eV are assigned to Pt0 and Pt2+ respectively [32]. Comparing the Pt4f spectra on fresh and deactivated catalyst, it is speculated that the valence of Pt species did not change significantly during the deactivation process. For the fresh catalyst, a small quantity of Pt2+ species exist, and then they are reduced to Pt0 species during the co-oxidation reaction. The reduction mechanism of Pt2+ species may be similar to that of Au+ species on fresh catalyst. Nevertheless, the surface atomic concentrations of Au and Pt species on the deactivated catalyst (0.38% and 0.39%) measured by XPS are lower than that on the fresh catalyst (0.45% and 0.47%). Flytzani-Stephanopoulos et al. reported that the content of surface Au on Au/CeO2 decreases after preferential oxidation (PROX) reaction. They pointed out that only Au species that is strongly bound to CeO2 appears to be involved in catalyzing the PROX reaction [33,34]. Furthermore, Wang et al. [15] proposed that the disappearance of Auδ+ may indicates the destruction of the strong interaction between Au and CeO2 and a decrease in the amount of Au that is strongly bound to CeO2 in the deactivated catalyst. Therefore, the decrease of surface Au and Pt species concentrations on Pt-Au/TiO2-CeO2 catalyst suggests the destruction of the strong interaction between Au, Pt and CeO2 in the deactivated catalyst. Fig. 6 shows Ce3d, Ti2p, C1 s, and O1 s XPS spectra of the fresh and deactivated Pt-Au/TiO2-CeO2 catalysts. The Ce3d core level spectra of the catalyst include eight components. The bands (labeled as u′ and v′) are assigned to the Ce3+ species. The bands (labeled as u, u′′, u′′′, v, v′′, and v′′′) are attributed to Ce4+ species [35]. The intensities of the signals of u′ and v′ in the fresh catalyst are stronger than that in the deactivated catalyst, meaning the decrease of Ce3+ species content during the co-oxidation reaction. More Ce3+ species promote the interaction between Ce species and the nearby atoms [36]. Guzman et al. [33] reported that Au species contacted with Ce or an oxygen vacancy might possess a positive charge. Chen et al. [37] also proposed that there was charge transfer from Au species to Ce, leading to a higher concentration of Auδ+ species and Ce3+species, although there was no Ce-Au bonding. It can reasonably illustrate the presence of Au+, Pt2+ and Ce3+ species in the fresh catalyst. Therefore the decrease of Ce3+ species concentration on the deactivated catalyst suggests the reduction of the interaction between CeO2, Pt and Au species, which is accordant with Au species XPS results. For Ti2p XPS spectra, the peaks at 456.8 eV and 459.9 eV are attributed to Ti3+ and Ti4+ species, respectively [38]. The content of Ti4+ species (7.5%) in the deactivated catalyst is lower than that (9.1%) in the fresh catalyst, which indicates a reduction of the interaction between TiO2 and CeO2 [39]. The surface Ti/Ce atomic ratios are 0.10 and 0.12 for the fresh and the deactivated catalysts, suggesting that the cerium-rich structure has been modified [21]. The C1 s spectra presents two different carbon species: adventitious carbon species (284.7 eV), and carbonate-like species (formate and carbonate species) (288.8 eV) [21]. Carbonate-like species content on the deactivated catalyst is higher than that on the fresh catalyst, evidently proving that carbonate-like species were generated on the catalyst during the co-oxidation reaction. Carbonate-like species covered the active sites, inhibited the effective activation of O2 and weakened interaction between Au, Pt species and the support. In O1 s spectra, the peaks at 529.7, 531.1 and 533.3 eV are ascribed to lattice oxygen of CeO2 and titanium oxide, carbonate and chemisorbed oxygen, and hydroxides species, respectively [40]. For the deactivated catalyst, the peak for lattice oxygen slightly shifts to the higher BE value than that for the fresh catalyst, which may be caused by the decrease of the surface Ce atomic concentration. Moreover, the peak at 531.1 eV is much stronger than that on the fresh catalyst, meaning that large amounts of carbonate-like species accumulate on the deactivated catalyst surface. In addition, the presence of the peak at 533.3 eV indicates the massive production of H2O species on the deactivated catalyst. Accumulation of numerous carbonate-like and production of H2O species on the active sites may inhibit the effective O2 adsorption and weaken the interaction between active species and support oxides, resulting in the decrease of catalytic activity [18]. In short, XPS results illustrate the chemical property of Pt-Au/TiO2-CeO2 catalyst changes after the co-oxidation of HCHO, H2 and CO at room temperature. The cationic Au and Pt species are reduced to metallic Au and Pt species with the decreasing of Ce3+ species content. In addition, the surface structure of CeO2 is modified, the accumulation of carbonate-like species and production of H2O species are also observed. The chemical and structural transformation may account for the deactivation of Pt-Au/TiO2–CeO2 catalyst. The XPS results show the accumulation of the carbonate-like species and water on the deactivated catalyst. Since carbonaceous species and water can be removed through calcination under air, O2-TPO is carried out to confirm the presence of these species on deactivated catalyst. During the O2-TPO test, the deactivated catalyst was pretreated with a He flow at 120 °C for 1 h, therefore the adsorbed H2O and CO2 at lower temperature should desorb from the deactivated catalyst. In Fig. 7 , CO2 and H2O are detected at 150–250 °C on the deactivated catalyst. Carbon can be oxidized in to CO2 at high temperature (>400 °C) [41], therefore CO2 is probably generated from the carbonate-like species. The production of H2O is mainly from the evaporation of production water and degradation of carbonate-like species. It can be concluded that the presence of CO2 and H2O during O2-TPO test proves the existence of carbonate-like species. Carbonate-like species could inhibit the effective O2 activation and decrease the catalytic activity. O2 consumption can be observed with the generation of CO2. There are three pathways for the O2 consumption. Firstly, decomposition of carbonate-like species should consume O2 and the consumption of oxygen is mainly attributed to degradation of carbonate-like species. Secondly, the consumption of O2 may be a part attributable to supply the defect of lattice oxygen as observed by the peak at 322 K in TPR (Fig. 4). Moreover, the oxidation of Ce3+ and Ti3+ species also consume O2. O2-TPO results suggest the existence of carbonate-like species and water, which is accordant with the XPS results. 3.3 In-situ DRIFTS study of reaction mechanism In order to gain further insights into the reaction mechanism of co-oxidation of HCHO, H2 and CO, in-situ DRIFT spectra of the fresh Pt-Au/TiO2-CeO2 catalyst were investigated under different gas streams at 25 °C. Nine distinct bands present in the in-situ DRIFT spectra. Bands at 3692 and 3421 cm−1 can be assigned to hydroxyl groups υ(OH) stemmed from the adsorbed water (HOH) [42–46] and isolated hydroxyl groups υ(OH) generated from the decomposition of OOH species [47]. 2840 cm−1 band could be attributed to υ(CH) of formate species [37]. 2166 and 2092 cm−1 bands can be assigned to CO adsorbed on Au species [15,48,49] and CO adsorbed on Pt species [23,50,51]. 1670 and 1640 cm−1 bands are attributed to production water δ(HOH) originated from the oxidation of H2 [49] and adsorbed water δ(HOH) [39]. 1590 cm−1 band is assigned to asymmetric υas(COO) stretch of carbonates-like species (formate species or carbonates species) [37]. 1460 and 1386 cm-1 bands can be assigned to symmetric υs(COO) stretch of carbonates-like species (formate species or carbonates species) [37].(Table 1 ). The combination of the adsorbed oxygen and adsorbed hydrogen brought out OOH species, and OOH species are further decomposed into isolated hydroxyl groups [47,52]. Isolated hydroxyl groups can be reacted with adsorbed hydrogen, generating production water. In Fig. 8 a, the peaks at 3692 (hydroxyl groups) and 3421 cm−1 (isolated hydroxyl groups υ(OH)) present negative peak, indicating that OH species participate in the CO oxidation. Previous studies showed that OH species as the active species can effectively oxidize the reactant, enhancing the oxidation reaction [22,53]. CO species gradually accumulate on the catalyst surface with the formation of carbonate species. Fig. 8 b presents the in situ DRIFT spectra of the Pt-Au/TiO2-CeO2 catalyst under H2/Air. Intensity change of peaks at 3692 and 3421 cm-1 indicates that massive OOH species were decomposed into OH species. Intensity change of peak at 1670 cm-1 (water δ(HOH)) means that H2O species are gradually formed. The peak of adsorbed water is at 1640 cm−1, however production H2O species shifts to high wavenumber. It means that H2O species may be strongly adsorbed on active sites and cause the deactivation of catalyst [22]. Furthermore, the production H2O species can condense inside the pores, and consequently the mass transfer of CO, HCHO and H2 to the catalytic sites will be strongly inhibited [21]. In Fig. 8c, no peaks assigned to formaldehyde are tested, suggesting that the adsorbed HCHO could be immediately oxidized on the catalyst. Massive formate species are gradually adsorbed on the catalyst surface according to the peaks intensity at 1590, 1460 and 1386 cm−1. In Fig. 9 a, intensity of the band at 3421 cm−1 is weaker than that in Fig. 8b, indicating that the CO has a negative influence on the H2 oxidation. Previous studies results also show the similar results, due to the CO self-poisoning effect on Pt active species [12,13]. Moreover, intensity of the band at 1590 cm−1 is stronger than that in Fig. 8a, suggesting that H2 promotes the CO oxidation. Wang et al. [21] and Piccolo et al. [47] have proposed that H2 promotion for the CO oxidation is due to the reaction between OOH species or OH species and adsorbed CO species. In Fig. 9b, intensity of the band at 1590 cm−1 is obviously weaker than that in Fig. 8c, which suggests that the presence of CO inhibits the HCHO oxidation because of CO accumulation and self-poisoning effect over Pt catalysts [12,13]. Intensity of the band at 1590 cm−1 in Fig. 9c is stronger than that in Fig. 8c. It indicates that H2 greatly improves the HCHO oxidation and may be due to the highly active OOH species or OH species. Chen et al. [37] have reported that water exhibits positive effect on the HCHO oxidation, due to that water can generate OH species and enhance HCHO removal. Intensity of the band at 1590 cm−1 in Fig. 9d is stronger than that in Fig. 9b, suggesting the H2 promotion on the oxidation HCHO and CO. Intensity of the bands at 1670 and 1590 cm−1 in Fig. 9d are weaker than that in Fig. 9c, showing the presence of CO restrains the oxidation of HCHO and H2. Therefore, CO inhibits the oxidation of H2 and HCHO, and H2 promotes the oxidation of CO and HCHO during co-oxidation reaction. 3.4 Origins of the deactivation on the Pt-Au/TiO2-CeO2 catalyst Generally, Au particle only with small particle size (<30 Å) was reported to be reactive in the atmosphere [54]. To some extent, Au catalyst activity for CO oxidation decreases with the increase of Au species particle size. The HRTEM and XRD results of the fresh and deactivated Pt-Au/TiO2-CeO2 catalysts present the well-dispersion of Pt and Au particles after reaction, indicating the catalyst deactivation probably does not origin from the growth of Pt and Au particles. The catalytic activity and adsorption/desorption behaviors of Au+ species were generally reported to be different from that of Au0 species. For example, in CO oxidation, Au+ species were the active components, while Au0 species were facile deactivated with increasing the reaction time [28]. These could be due to the adsorption of O2 on cationic Au species. The XPS and H2-TPR results in this study show the concentrations of cationic Au and Pt species significantly decreases on the deactivated catalyst, indicating the change in the chemical state of Pt and Au species. Therefore, it can be concluded that the reduction of Au+ and Pt+ species mainly account for the deactivation of Pt-Au/TiO2-CeO2 catalyst. The accumulation of intermediates such as carbonate species and water could also lead to the deactivation of catalyst. On the one hand, carbonate species inhibited the effective O2 activation and led to a reduction of interaction between active species and the support as shown in water-gas shift reaction on Pt/CeO2 catalyst [18,55–57]. In this study, the decrease of surface Au and Pt species concentrations may indicate that the strong interaction between Au and Pt species and support is reduction. The decrease of Ce3+ species amount surrounding Pt and Au species particles may leads to the decrease of the defects sites for oxygen activation. On the other hand, the deactivation of the Pt-Au/TiO2-CeO2 catalyst by the accumulation of carbonates-like and production H2O species may also be caused through covering the active sites. When the active sites are fully blocked by the carbonates-like and production H2O species, catalyst is completely deactivated. Peak area of 1670 and 1590 cm−1 in Fig. 9c is higher than that in Fig. 9d, suggesting that the presence of CO hinders the formation of carbonates-like and production H2O species on catalyst. It is attributed to the CO self-poisoning effect on Pt active species [55]. So, CO inhibits the oxidation of H2 and HCHO during co-oxidation reaction, which accounts for the decrease of H2 and HCHO conversions in Fig. 1. Peak area of 1590 cm−1 in Fig. 9d is higher than that in Fig. 9b, which suggests that H2 enhances the generation of carbonates-like species. It is caused by the formation of highly active OOH species or OH species during H2 oxidation [37]. Consequently, H2 promotes the CO and HCHO oxidation during the co-oxidation reaction. 4 Conclusions The origins of the deactivation of the Pt-Au/TiO2-CeO2 catalyst during the co-oxidation of CO, HCHO and H2 at room temperature were studied. Based on the above results, the deactivation of the catalyst was mainly attributed to the intrinsic change in the chemical state of the Au, Pt and Ce species, the formation of carbonates-like and production H2O species on catalyst active sites. Continuous accumulation of carbonates-like and production H2O species finally caused the total deactivation. Identification of key intermediate species suggests that mutual influence between CO, HCHO and H2 reactants are as follows: CO inhibited the oxidation of H2 and HCHO, and H2 promoted the oxidation of CO and HCHO during co-oxidation reaction. coredata.dc:description: The deactivation origins of the Pt-Au/TiO2-CeO2 catalyst for co-oxidation of formaldehyde (HCHO), hydrogen (H2) and carbon monoxide (CO) at room temperature were studied by means of XRD, BET, H2-TPR, O2-TPD, XPS and in-situ DRIFTS. The results suggested that the catalyst deactivation was mainly caused by the reduction of Au+ species, the decrease of Ce3+ species and interaction weakness between active components and support. Moreover, during the co-oxidation process, CO showed a negative influence on the oxidation of HCHO and H2 due to the CO self-poisoning effect, whereas H2 promoted the oxidation of HCHO and CO because of the generation of OOH and OH active intermediates from the H2 oxidation. Meanwhile, the accumulations of carbonate-like species as well as the production of H2O on the deactivated catalyst were also observed, accounting for the complete catalyst deactivation.
coredata.dc:title: Deactivation of Pt-Au/TiO2-CeO2 catalyst for co-oxidation of HCHO, H2 and CO at room temperature: Degradations of active sites and mutual influence between reactants
